questions.question: What does the 'Five Nines' concept mean for system availability?
options: The system is available 99.999% of the time [cite: 1080]
The system has 5.26 hours of downtime per year
The system is available 99.9% of the time
The system has 9 minutes of downtime per month
questions.answer: The system is available 99.999% of the time [cite: 1080]

questions.question: Achieving 'Five Nines' availability means that planned and unplanned downtime is less than:
Which of these is NOT listed as a principle for designing a High Availability system?
What is the purpose of 'Asset Management' in improving availability?
options: To know what hardware and software assets an organization has in order to protect them [cite: 1106]
To assign all resources into a group based on common characteristics [cite: 1119]
To reduce the severity of a loss from occurring [cite: 1126]
To replace all hardware assets every five years
questions.answer: To know what hardware and software assets an organization has in order to protect them [cite: 1106]

questions.question: The 'CVE' (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) is a dictionary of standard identifiers for:
Which principle of 'Defense in Depth' involves restricting access so that users only have the level of access required to do their job?
In 'Defense in Depth', what does the principle of 'Diversity' mean?
options: Changing the controls and procedures at different layers [cite: 1137]
Hiding information about the system, like OS version [cite: 1140]
questions.answer: Changing the controls and procedures at different layers [cite: 1137]

questions.question: A component that is the 'weak link in the chain' and can cause disruption of an organization's operations if it fails is called a:
What is 'N+1 redundancy'?
options: A system where components (N) have at least one backup component (+1) [cite: 1151, 1152]
A system that is N times more complex and has one backup
A system that requires N+1 administrators to manage
A system that adds one additional layer of security
questions.answer: A system where components (N) have at least one backup component (+1) [cite: 1151, 1152]

questions.question: In RAID, which term describes the technique of writing data across multiple drives?
In RAID, which term describes the technique of storing duplicate data on a second drive?
What is the basic function of the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)?
options: To provide load balancing between routers
To prevent loops on a network when switches are interconnected via multiple paths [cite: 1166]
To provide a virtual router for first-hop redundancy
To encrypt data as it crosses the network
questions.answer: To prevent loops on a network when switches are interconnected via multiple paths [cite: 1166]

questions.question: The ability of a network to dynamically recover from the failure of a router acting as a default gateway is known as:
Which router redundancy protocol protects data from a failed router while ALSO allowing load balancing between a group of redundant routers?
Which type of location redundancy synchronizes both locations in real time and requires high bandwidth?
What is the name of the team assembled by an organization to manage the response to an incident?
Which phase of incident response involves investigating the cause of the incident and asking questions to better understand the threat?
What is the key difference between an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) and an Intrusion Prevention System (IPS)?
options: An IDS is passive and monitors, while an IPS is inline and can immediately address a problem [cite: 1218, 1219]
An IPS is passive and monitors, while an IDS is inline and can immediately address a problem
An IDS uses NetFlow, while an IPS uses IPFIX
An IDS is for hardware, while an IPS is for software
questions.answer: An IDS is passive and monitors, while an IPS is inline and can immediately address a problem [cite: 1218, 1219]

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a 'human-caused' disaster?
options: Utility power failures or communication outages [cite: 1238]
questions.answer: Utility power failures or communication outages [cite: 1238]
